Winter School 2012 Winter School "Geometric Evolution Equations and Related Topics" Regensburg, October 8th-10th, 2012 Home Program Registration Participants General information Contact Welcome The scope of this winter school is to bring together researchers working on geometric evolution equations. The presentations will cover topics on Geometric evolution equations, in particular: Mean curvature and Willmore flow Contact angle problems Singular Limits of reaction diffusion equations Everybody interested in these topics is welcome to attend the Winter School. Besides the talks by the main speakers there will be exercise classes. Confirmed invited speakers Giovanni Bellettini (Rome) Klaus Ecker (Berlin) Oliver Schnürer (Konstanz) Organizers: Helmut Abels (Regensburg) Harald Garcke (Regensburg) Lars Müller (Regensburg) Supported by: Johannes-Kepler-Forschungszentrum (University of Regensburg), Graduiertenkolleg "Curvature, Cycles, and Cohomology" (Universität Regensburg) View of the Stone Bridge and the picturesque Old Town of Regensburg (UNESCO World Heritage). (Photo: Tourist Office Regensburg)

All talks will be presented in M104, whereas coffee will be served in M103. The conferrence dinner will be served in restaurant "Vitus" (Hinter der Grieb 8, 93047 Regensburg). Titles and abstracts: Giovanni Bellettini: "Mean curvature flow and singular perturbations" In this course we will show the relations between mean curvature flow of an hypersurface and the asymptotic limits of solutions of the parabolic Ginzburg-Landau equations. We will prove convergence of solutions to mean curvature flow for short times, in particular before the onset of singularities. For what concerns the analogous problem for longer times, we will discuss some aspects of the convergence to a properly defined weak solution. Klaus Ecker: "Regularity theory for mean curvature flow" In this lecture series we consider the evolution of hypersurfaces in normal direction with speed given by the mean curvature function. This is a nonlinear geometrically very natural heat like system whose solutions tend to develop singularities in finite time. We will study the structure of the singular set using methods from differential geometry, partial differential equations and geometric measure theory. Some basic background material for these areas will be provided in the lectures. There will also be exercises for the audience. The reference for this lectures course is the monograph by the lecturer. Oliver Schnürer: "Asymptotics for geometric evolution equations" In these lectures (Link), we study hypersurfaces that solve geometric evolution equations. The normal velocity of the evolving hypersurfaces depends on their Gauß or mean curvature. We will discuss the asymptotic behaviour of those solutions for large times. Depending on the initial conditions there are many known results that describe different ways solutions might evolve. We will focus on two aspects related to the work of the lecturer: Hypersurfaces that become round as they shrink to points. The behaviour of complete non-compact solutions.
